projectDesc.p: To the tune “Water Dragon Chant”—"They Look like Flowers"is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the tune “Water Dragon Chant”—"They Look like Flowers"
They look like flowers but also do not look like them.
No one treasures them, letting them fall.
They were tossed to the side of the road near home.
Yet, when you think about it,
Although they seem insentient, they do have thoughts.
They are the gentle heart worn out by worries,
The drowsy charming eyes,
Closed again as they are just about to open.
Their dreams ride with the wind for a thousand miles,
Searching for where their men have gone,
Yet, they are woken by the orioles.
I do not regret that these flowers have all flown away
But regret that in the western garden,
The fallen red petals cannot be stitched back together.
After the rain at dawn,
Where are their traces now?
There is a pool of shattered duckweed.
The spring charm divides into three,
Two become dust,
One turns into flowing water.
Look at them carefully:
Those are not willow catkins,
The little dots are the tears of the ones that were parted from each other.
